label: Letter 1 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, July 20, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a book he had recently read and arguing multiple points as to why they should sell Medway Plantation after the war. This letter is a copy sent to New York.

Copy to
1528 31st. Street, Washington.
Original to London
July 20, 1 43
Mrs Sidney J. Legendre
National City Bank of New York,
11 Waterloo Place
London.
Dear Gertie,
Your letters of July 10th and 14th arrived
with this evenings mail at the office and I brought them
home to read and rexread them. I laughed when I read that
Wing Peter said we were the stars of surfboarding. That
is as ridiculous as the Dillingham story about my being
drunk. Morris and I have never ridden a wave all the waxy
in, we fall off almost immediately, and to boot never even
catch more than two waves an afternoon, although we may try
for one hundred. It seems th t it requires a real knack
and we just have n t been able to get it. As I told you in
my last letter there has not been any surf for three weeks
and as a result we have sto[pp]ed going ot the outrigger.
This afternoon weplayed tennis again and it was great fun.
Old man Morris beat me two sets easily, without even
making an effort and then we came home and cooked a marvelous
casserole of chicken, lima beans and rice. Everything
fresh out of a can and very good. After eating until our
stomachs were popping we serenly went to our own rooms, s[H]ut
the doors and lay down on our beds. He to read and I to
write you.
The book "Thunder in Heaven"is written by a 
women. Don't you remember several years ago she wrote a
book and we read the synopisis of it in the readers digest.
It was about a girl raised on a ranch on the island of Hawai
by her farther who was the manager. You liked it so much.
She is also the Author of Thunder in Heaven[,]which is rather
depressing [book] as the girl foolishly kills her own husba[N]d when
there is nothing the matter with him. There is too much
sadness in the orld without reading about it in books.
I have not heard from you as to whether Anderson is defini[ly]
going to handle my books and whether instructions have be
given to the Guaranty Trust Co. to send him a l the neces
information. Please let me know about this.
I too remember some of the lovely things we di
together at Medway, and for all we know we may be delight[ed]
to end up living there the rest of our lives. However
my arguments against it are:
[End Page 1]
1. It is too expensive. Beyond our income so that
running it is like running a business always trying
to meet thepayroll and yet never having the fun or the
possibility of getting ahead of the expensi-ses. 
2. We were isolated from all other people and sources of  
amusment except those created by o[u]rselves. The result was
that we depended -upon one andrther for our exercises and 
pleasures. This would have been ideal had we been evenly
blessed with energy. Unforturately you possessed too much
and I too little for a proper balance and after I was whipped
from a monnings ride you were just limbered up for an afternoons
tennis or quail shooting. There was no other form of amus-  
for you and if I did not go out again you would be left alone
with nothing to do. You remember we discussed this often.
The result of this of course was that I was always tired,
to tired to want to see peoole, who we[r]e always there, to
tired to do anthiny byt lie on the sofa at the end of the
day a expire.
3. It is an impossible pl ce to bring up children. I feel  
we did Landine a great wrong by forcing her to live in a  
boarxding house with a nurse all her formative years and I
would like to give Bo a better chance.
4. I do not want to cope [w]ith the ever breaking down of the 
house, the tractors, the banks etc. No matter whether we
walked , rode or sat on the terrace the conversation invariably
turned to "this bridge has to be fixed. Did'nt you just 
hear a shot, I think it must bepoachers, These porch chairs
are terrible, we must have them recovered. I think this - H;
horse is lame in the front foot. You know how it was[,]one
petty worry after another.
Where we will live I do not know. I do not want to live
in a city at all. In fact would hate it. But I do want t o
live near enough to other people so that we can have tennis
golf, and riding, If we want to farm a little there will
be someone to talk to about it. etc. Hawaii may not be
right, I do not know. We will try and live in different
places until we find some thing that appeals to us both.
Providing of course that this war does not run into another
one before I am even released from the service.
My Navy Number is 159922 and my commanding officer is
Captain W.G. Goggins. I should think the Navy would have
that information in their files and it would not be necessry
forthem to ask you.
Goodbye darling, I have not the faintsest idea whether
this letter will find you abroad or in the states, but
whereever you are it carries all my love, both the copy
and the original.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
